title: Population Variant Database Builder
description: Generate comprehensive variant catalogues with population frequencies from whole genome sequences. content:
Variant Catalogue: Population Variant Database Builder

Create Comprehensive Population Variant Databases from Whole Genome Sequences

The Variant Catalogue pipeline generates systematic lists of genetic variants and their frequencies across populations, enabling large-scale genomic studies, disease association research, and reference database construction for clinical genomics.

What is a Variant Catalogue?

A variant catalogue is a comprehensive database containing:

  • Variant coordinates: Precise genomic locations of SNVs, indels, and structural variants

  • Population frequencies: Allele frequencies across different populations and cohorts

  • Functional annotations: Impact predictions, gene context, and clinical significance

  • Quality metrics: Confidence scores, read depth, and validation statistics

Key Features

Comprehensive Workflow

  • Mapping Subworkflow: BWA alignment with quality control using FastQC and Mosdepth

  • SNV/Indel Detection: DeepVariant for accurate variant calling, GLnexus for joint genotyping

  • Mitochondrial Analysis: GATK-based mtDNA variant detection with specialized calling parameters

  • Variant Aggregation: Hail for scalable population-level variant aggregation and frequency calculation

  • Annotation: VEP (Variant Effect Predictor) for comprehensive functional annotation

Tools and Technologies

  • Alignment: BWA, Trimmomatic, Samtools

  • Quality Control: FastQC, Mosdepth for coverage analysis

  • Variant Calling: DeepVariant (state-of-the-art deep learning caller), GATK for mitochondrial variants

  • Joint Genotyping: GLnexus for population-scale variant consolidation

  • Population Analysis: Hail for scalable genomic data analysis

  • Annotation: VEP with comprehensive database resources

Scientific Applications

Population Genomics

  • Reference databases: Build population-specific variant frequency databases

  • Rare variant discovery: Identify low-frequency variants across large cohorts

  • Population structure: Analyze genetic diversity and population stratification

  • Evolutionary studies: Track variant distributions across different populations

Clinical Genomics

  • Variant filtering: Use population frequencies to filter benign variants in diagnostic workflows

  • Pathogenicity assessment: Compare patient variants against population baselines

  • Carrier screening: Identify disease-causing variant frequencies for genetic counseling

  • Pharmacogenomics: Build databases of drug response variants across populations

Disease Association

  • GWAS support: Provide frequency data for genome-wide association studies

  • Case-control studies: Compare variant frequencies between affected and control populations

  • Risk prediction: Build polygenic risk score databases

  • Precision medicine: Identify actionable variants and their population distributions

Reference Genome Selection

Choose the appropriate reference genome for your study:

  • GRCh38/hg38: Latest human reference genome (recommended)

  • GRCh37/hg19: Previous human reference, widely used for compatibility

  • CHM13: Telomere-to-telomere human reference for complete genome coverage

Sample Sheet Format

Your CSV samplesheet defines the cohort for variant catalogue generation:

sample,fastq_1,fastq_2,population,cohort
Individual_001,Ind001_R1.fastq.gz,Ind001_R2.fastq.gz,EUR,cohort1
Individual_002,Ind002_R1.fastq.gz,Ind002_R2.fastq.gz,EUR,cohort1
Individual_003,Ind003_R1.fastq.gz,Ind003_R2.fastq.gz,AFR,cohort1
Individual_004,Ind004_R1.fastq.gz,Ind004_R2.fastq.gz,EAS,cohort1

Column Descriptions:

  • sample: Unique sample identifier (no spaces, alphanumeric and underscores only)

  • fastq_1: Path to Read 1 FASTQ file (paired-end whole genome sequencing)

  • fastq_2: Path to Read 2 FASTQ file

  • population: Population code (e.g., EUR, AFR, EAS, SAS, AMR) - optional but useful for stratification

  • cohort: Study cohort identifier - optional for multi-cohort studies

Sequencing Requirements

Data Type

  • Whole Genome Sequencing (WGS): Required for comprehensive variant catalogue

  • Coverage: Minimum 30x depth recommended, 50x+ ideal for rare variant detection

  • Read Type: Paired-end reads (2x100bp or 2x150bp)

  • Quality: High-quality Illumina sequencing data

Cohort Size Considerations

  • Small cohorts (10-50 samples): Suitable for pilot studies and rare disease families

  • Medium cohorts (50-500 samples): Population-specific variant databases

  • Large cohorts (500+ samples): Comprehensive population reference databases

Output Files

Variant Catalogue Data

  • VCF files: Multi-sample VCF with all variants and genotypes

  • Frequency tables: Variant frequencies by population and cohort

  • Annotated variants: VEP annotations including functional predictions and clinical significance

  • Summary statistics: Variant counts, allele frequency distributions, and quality metrics

Quality Control Reports

  • Alignment QC: Mapping statistics, coverage uniformity, duplicate rates

  • Variant QC: Transition/transversion ratios, Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium tests

  • Sample QC: Per-sample variant counts, heterozygosity rates, relatedness checks

  • MultiQC report: Comprehensive quality metrics across all samples

Mitochondrial Variants

  • mtDNA VCF: Mitochondrial variants with haplogroup information

  • Heteroplasmy: Frequencies of mitochondrial variant heteroplasmy

  • Coverage: Mitochondrial genome coverage statistics

Downstream Applications

  • Database integration: Import into variant databases (e.g., gnomAD-style resources)

  • Clinical filtering: Use as control population for diagnostic variant filtering

  • Research studies: Foundation for GWAS, rare disease studies, and population genetics

  • Quality control: Benchmark dataset for validation of variant calling pipelines

Pipeline Status and Citation

Development Status: This pipeline is currently in active development. Check the nf-core website for the latest updates and stable releases.

Citation: If you use nf-core/variantcatalogue in your research, please cite:

Correard et al., 2022. DOI: 10.1101/2022.10.03.508010

Technical Details

  • Built with Nextflow DSL2: Modern workflow language with reproducible execution

  • Container support: Docker and Singularity for complete reproducibility

  • Cloud-ready: Optimized for AWS, Google Cloud, and Azure execution

  • Scalable: Efficiently processes cohorts from tens to thousands of samples

  • nf-core standards: Follows best practices for quality, documentation, and testing

Perfect for: Population genomics • Disease gene discovery • Reference database construction • Clinical variant interpretation • Evolutionary genetics • Rare variant studies • Pharmacogenomics • Precision medicine initiatives

Built with Nextflow • Powered by nf-core/variantcatalogue • Containerized execution • Community-driven development
